name: Stephanie van Willigenburg
content:
Stephanie van Willigenburg is a professor of mathematics at the University of British Columbia[1] whose research is in the field of algebraic combinatorics and concerns quasisymmetric functions. Together with James Haglund, Kurt Luoto and Sarah Mason, she introduced the quasisymmetric Schur functions, which form a basis for quasisymmetric functions.[HLM]
 van Willigenburg earned her Ph.D. in 1997 at the University of St. Andrews under the joint supervision of Edmund F. Robertson and Michael D. Atkinson, with a thesis titled The Descent Algebras of Coxeter Groups.[2] She was awarded the Krieger–Nelson Prize in 2017[3] by the Canadian Mathematical Society.
raw:
Canadian mathematician
Stephanie van Willigenburg is a professor of mathematics at the University of British Columbia[1] whose research is in the field of algebraic combinatorics and concerns quasisymmetric functions. Together with James Haglund, Kurt Luoto and Sarah Mason, she introduced the quasisymmetric Schur functions, which form a basis for quasisymmetric functions.[HLM]
van Willigenburg earned her Ph.D. in 1997 at the University of St. Andrews under the joint supervision of Edmund F. Robertson and Michael D. Atkinson, with a thesis titled The Descent Algebras of Coxeter Groups.[2] She was awarded the Krieger–Nelson Prize in 2017[3] by the Canadian Mathematical Society.

Selected publications[edit]


HLM.
Haglund, J.; Luoto, K.; Mason, S.; van Willigenburg, S. (2011), "Quasisymmetric Schur functions", Journal of Combinatorial Theory, Series A, 118 (2): 463–490, arXiv:0810.2489, doi:10.1016/j.jcta.2009.11.002
